raw_text:
Guantanamo four questioned
 
 The four Britons freed from US custody in Guantanamo Bay are expected to be allowed a visit by one relative.
 
 Moazzam Begg, Martin Mubanga, Feroz Abbasi and Richard Belmar were held for three years, accused of al-Qaeda links. Mr Begg's father, Azmat, said he had been told he could see his son for 20 minutes and would say he was "a hero". The men are being held at London's Paddington Green police station, where they are expected to be questioned by UK anti-terror officers. But Louise Christian, the lawyer representing Mr Abbasi and Mr Mubanga, said the families would be reunited with the men away from the station. Before being driven by police from Birmingham to London, Azmat Begg said he was concerned for his son Moazzam's mental state and was looking forward to giving him a hug. As Azmat Begg arrived at the London police station, there appeared to be some confusion as to the visiting arrangements. Police have said they have a duty to investigate the men, who were arrested on their return to the UK. But Metropolitan Police Commissioner Sir John Stevens said evidence obtained by MI5 while the four were in Cuba was "absolutely" inadmissible in UK courts. In an interview with the Independent, Sir John said his officers would have to find other evidence before the suspects could be tried in the UK.
 
 He told the newspaper: "If an admission is made, it is a totally different ball game... it could be used as evidence. "The options are: if there is enough evidence they will be charged. If not they will be released as soon as possible." The men have been allowed to meet their lawyers. Louise Christian said that after being "tortured and abused" at Guantanamo Bay, the men's arrest was unfair and inappropriate. She told BBC News she remained very concerned about their psychological state. Gareth Peirce, lawyer for Mr Begg, said she was shocked at the condition of the men and appalled that the authorities felt the need to detain them. Washington has claimed all four were "enemy combatants" who trained at camps run by al-Qaeda. The Pentagon says they were freed after the UK government promised they would not be a threat to the national security of the US or any of its allies.
 
 The detainees were immediately arrested under Section 41 of the Terrorism Act 2000 when they landed at RAF Northolt, west London, on Tuesday. Massoud Shadjareh, from the Muslim Safety Forum, said: "What sort of homecoming is this? They are innocent people." The Muslim Council of Britain urged that the men should receive counselling and medical help. "We want these men to be returned into the arms of their waiting family," said Iqbal Sacranie, secretary general of the council.
llama3.2:1b: Four British citizens, Moazzam Begg, Martin Mubanga, Feroz Abbasi, and Richard Belmar, were freed from US custody in Guantanamo Bay after three years.
They are being held at London's Paddington Green police station for questioning on suspicion of al-Qaeda links.
The families plan to visit them, but UK authorities have expressed concerns about their mental state and the need for evidence before charges can be considered.
The men have already met with their lawyers and received permission to meet relatives without being detained.
llama3.2:3b: Four British men held at Guantanamo Bay for three years were released and are being questioned by UK anti-terror officers before meeting with relatives.
The men's lawyers claim they were unfairly detained and tortured, while US authorities say they trained with al-Qaeda.
A court inadmissible evidence obtained during their detention, but the men face investigation under the Terrorism Act 2000.
gemma2:2b: Four Britons freed from Guantanamo Bay are expected to meet with their families.
They were held for three years on suspicion of al-Qaeda links and face questioning by UK anti-terror officers.
Their lawyer claims they were unfairly arrested and abused.
The men's release is conditional on the UK government assuring US authorities they pose no threat.
qwen2.5:0.5b: The four British soldiers released from Guantanamo Bay are expected to meet with their lawyers.
They were arrested in September 2013 and held for three years without trial after being accused of al-Qaeda connections.
The men have been allowed a visit by one relative.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Four Britons who were freed from Guantanamo Bay detention are set for a visit by relatives; they're to be questioned by UK anti-terror officers but not at London's Paddington Green police station.
The men have been accused of al-Qaeda links and held for three years without trial.
They've faced psychological abuse in Cuba, while the Metropolitan Police claims evidence there is "absolutely" inadmissible in UK courts.
Washington maintains they were enemy combatants who trained with al-Qaeda camps.
qwen2.5:3b: The Guantanamo four Britons—Moazzam Begg, Martin Mubanga, Feroz Abbasi, and Richard Belmar—are set to visit one relative each at London’s Paddington Green police station.
Freed after three years in US custody, they were accused of al-Qaeda links but are now being questioned by UK anti-terror officers.
Azmat Begg (Moazzam's father) expressed hope for a 20-minute reunion with his son.
Police maintain their duty to investigate while admitting evidence from Guantanamo is not admissible in UK courts.
Both men and lawyers have expressed concerns about the detainees' mental state, with Louise Christian asserting the arrests were unfair.
The US claims they were enemy combatants trained by al-Qaeda, but UK authorities insist they are no longer a threat.
The British Muslim community supports the release of the detainees and calls for their reintegration into families.

tinyllama:1.1b:

The families were told they could see their loved ones for 20 minutes before the interviews, but Louise Christian, the lawyer representing Azmat Begg and his family, said she was concerned for her son's mental state.
Gareth Peircé, the lawyer for Azmat Begg, said all four were "enemy combatants" who trained at camps run by al-Qaeda.
The detained men are being held away from London's Paddington Green police station and have been allowed to see their families before questioning.
Concerned about their mental health, Azmat Begg's father said he would like to give his son a visit.
The Muslim Council of Britain urged that the men be returned into the arms of their waiting family.

Upon their return to the UK, they were arrested under the Terrorism Act 2000 and taken to London's Paddington Green police station for questioning.
Their families were allowed limited visits, and their lawyers criticized their detention, citing their alleged mistreatment at Guantanamo.

granite3.1-dense:2b: Four British men—Moazzam Begg, Martin Mubanga, Feroz Abbasi, and Richard Belmar—held for three years due to al-Qaeda links at Guantanamo Bay have been released from UK custody in London.
They are being held temporarily at Paddington Green police station, where they will be questioned by anti-terror officers.
The men's relatives are expected to have a 20-minute visit with their sons, who were allegedly "tortured and abused" during their detention in Cuba.
Metropolitan Police Commissioner Sir John Stevens stated that evidence obtained by MI5 while the men were at Guantanamo Bay is inadmissible in UK courts.
He emphasized that his officers must find alternative evidence before potentially charging or releasing them, as their current condition suggests they could be charged if enough evidence exists.
Lawyers for two of the men expressed concern about their psychological states and criticized the unfairness of their detention upon arrival in London.
Washington claims these individuals were "enemy combatants" who trained at al-Qaeda camps, while the UK government assured the US they would pose no threat to national security or allies if released.
The Muslim Council of Britain and other organizations have called for counseling and medical support for these men upon their return home.
Critics have described the detainees' reception as inappropriate, given their innocence.
